comments:
Version: 3.1.0
Build id: 200412140800

When I shut down Eclipse I got the "Internal errors occurred..." message before
the application quit. When the workbench was already shut down, a tiny dialog
came up informing me about internal errors and saying I should check the log.

Before, I was testing keybindings and CVS functionality in Eclipse.

I couldn't reproduce it on an empty workspace, but after it had occurred for the
first time it happened always for that specific workspace.

Here's the entry:

PresentablePart was not checking if the part had been disposed before setting
its bounds.

Fixed in HEAD. We should include this in M4.

Under what conditions can a PresentablePart still exist (and have its bounds 
set), but yet have disposed controls?

Because of the weird widget hierarchy we use to make DND work on all platforms,
the presentable part is a peer with the presentation. Therefore, SWT makes no
guarantees about which one will be disposed first.

SWT widget disposal can occur when the parent widget is disposed and it is not
always triggered by LayoutPart. This means that during disposal, the part can
exist for a short time without valid widgets. (Yes, there is a much better way
to do this, but this is how things work right now).

This error occurs because the ViewForm in the presentation triggered a layout
during the presentation's disposal code and the active part had already been
disposed but had not yet been removed from the layout.

I suspect a recent SWT change either caused an additional layout to be triggered
by ViewForm or changed the order of disposal between the presentation and part
(both of which would be valid changes and would explain why the bug is showing
up now in code that hasn't changed in a long time).
*** Bug 81331 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 81272 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
I've filed bug 81338 to add tests that excercise various disposal scenarios.
*** Bug 81340 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

FYI, the component framework will allow us to fix this class of problem (bugs
caused by the weird intermediate states of partially constructed or partially
disposed LayoutParts/WorkbenchParts).

In the component framework, construction and destruction are atomic
operations... but it will take quite a bit of refactoring before we can take
advantage of this everywhere in the workbench.

The error always happens when I am in the CVS Repository perspective when I 
shut down eclipse.

I can reproduce the error quite easily.  I substituted SWT from 3.1 M3 and 3.1 
M2 and the problem still occurs.  Therefore, I do not think this is due to an 
SWT change.  (Could not back as far as 3.0.1 because eclipse uses new API in 
CBanner.)

Sorry, I wasn't trying to lay blame. My point was that whatever change caused
this to happen isn't necessarily a bug, but the fact that we're not checking for
a disposed LayoutPart is.

While it may be a bug to not check for a disposed widget in LayoutPart, I 
think that work may be happening on shutdown that should not be and this could 
be a performance problem.  Since it only seems to happen in the CVS 
perspective, I think that some investigation should be done to figure out 
exactly what is the cause.

Adding Michael Valenta to the CC list - maybe he knows of some recent change 
in the CVS perspective which may help.
